intro: Baeria clevelandii, commonly known as the Cleveland's baeria, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. Its small, showy flowers are usually yellow or orange, and it produces achenes as its seeds. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
